sen.j: 荘園領主のために仕丁や京上夫（京都にて奉仕する）・鎌倉夫（鎌倉にて奉仕する）、兵士役を務めたり、在地において炭焼夫や草刈夫・佃などを行った。
sen.e: They served as a jicho (manservant doing odd jobs in a nobleman's house), Kyonoborifu (served in Kyoto), Kamakurafu (served in Kamakura) or soldier, or worked as a sumiyakifu (charcoal burner), kusakarifu (mower) or worked for tsukuda (directly-managed rice fields by a lord or an officer of shoen) in the local land.

These duties included serving as a soldier, a jicho (manservant doing odd jobs in a nobleman's house), Kyonoborifu (serving in Kyoto) or Kamakurafu (serving in Kamakura). Other duties included working in a local area as a sumiyakifu (charcoal burner), kusakarifu (mower) or working in a tsukuda (rice fields managed directly by a lord or officer of a shoen (manor)).

sen.j: 室町時代以後になると、守護大名や戦国大名あるいはその配下の国人によって動員され、軍夫・陣夫・人夫などとして奉仕した。
sen.e: After the Muromachi Period, Shugo daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords), Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) or local lords serving under them mobilized them, who served as a private soldier, serviceman or laborer.

After the Muromachi Period, Shugo daimyo (Japanese provincial military governors who later became daimyo, Japanese feudal lords), Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) or their subordinates would recruit for these duties, putting private soldiers, servicemen or laborers into service.
